title: Zara Pulls Controversial Ad that Activists Said Resembles Gaza After Calls for Boycott
description: Some activists said that the images were making light of the conflict.

title: The Voice Notes Poet Refaat Alareer Sent Before His Death
description: In a series of voice notes sent to TIME, the late poet reflected on the strength of Palestinians in Gaza.

title: The Global Immigration System Is Failing. There’s a Better Way
description: Around the world, states are failing global migrants and refugees. We need to rethink our approach away from deterrence.

title: Celebrating Hanukkah in the Face of Antisemitism
description: 'Hanukkah is a holiday about being particularly, proudly, even defiantly, Jewish,' writes Rabbi Diana Fersko.

title: The Supreme Court Rejects an Appeal Over Bans on Conversion Therapy for LGBTQ+ Children
description: The court's decision to avoid the case comes as efforts to limit the rights of LGBTQ kids have spread across the country.

title: Imprisoned Russian Opposition Leader Alexei Navalny Hasn’t Been Heard From in Six Days, According to His Aides
description: Navalny, who is serving a 19-year term on charges of extremism, was due to appear in court Monday via video but didn't.

title: Why America Still Doesn’t Have Fast Trains
description: For 70 years, the U.S. has failed to achieve faster trains—because it refuses to do what it takes to make them work.

title: People Around the World Go on Global Strike for a Ceasefire in Gaza
description: In the West Bank, which is under military occupation by Israeli forces, nearly all commercial activity has shut down.

title: Barbie Leads Golden Globe Nominations With 9, Followed Closely by Oppenheimer
description: Greta Gerwig's 'Barbie' dominated the Golden Globe Awards nominations. See the rest of the nods here.

title: What Happens When People Stop Taking the Weight Loss Drug Zepbound
description: Not all the benefits disappear.

title: COP28 Draft Climate Deal Floats Fossil Fuel Cuts for First Time
description: If the language stays, it would mark the first time in nearly 30 years that a call to cut fossil fuels made it into a UN climate summit deal.

title: Why It’s OK to Say No to That Party You’re Dreading
description: You're probably overestimating how much your absence will upset your host.

title: A Trip to See the Mona Lisa Is About to Get a Lot Pricier
description: The museum is raising ticket prices from €17 to €22 as prices in Paris balloon ahead of the 2024 Olympics.

title: How Mariah Carey’s 1994 ‘All I Want For Christmas Is You’ Still Dominates the Holiday Charts
description: For four years in a row, Mariah Carey’s festive anthem has topped Billboard’s Hot 100 chart—and 2023 may be no different.

title: Whistleblower Doctor Who Exposed China’s Rural AIDS Epidemic Dies at 95
description: The renowned Yaojie exposed the AIDS virus epidemic in rural China in the 1990s.

title: E.U. Reaches Deal on World’s First Comprehensive AI Rules
description: European Union negotiators have clinched a deal on the world's first comprehensive artificial intelligence rules

title: Final Members of K-Pop Band BTS Begin Mandatory South Korean Military Service
description: Singers RM, V, Jimin, and Jung Kook begin their duties this week, joining Jin, J-Hope, and Suga, who are already months into their conscription. The seven members of the popular K-pop band plan to reunite as a group sometime in 2025 after they finish their service.

title: Hong Kong’s ‘Patriots Only’ Local Elections Marked by Arrests, Low Turnout: What to Know
description: The record-low turnout is the latest sign of widespread discontent and rising apathy in the semi-autonomous Chinese enclave toward its pro-Beijing government.

title: U.S. Fighter Jet Crashes in Sea off South Korea
description: The incident comes less than two weeks after a U.S. Osprey aircraft crashed off the coast of Japan, killing its eight crew members, and months after another F-16 crashed in South Korean farmland during a training exercise.

title: Japan’s Prime Minister Fumio Kishida Reportedly Set to Purge Cabinet Amid Scandal
description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is set to replace as many as 15 ministers and junior ministers, the Asahi newspaper said, as he seeks to contain the fallout from a slush fund scandal threatening to paralyze his government.
